comments.commentBody:
jrkenti #47,

Thanks - nice catch. I updated the graphic in the main post.

Wonderful blog comments : )

Suejean (1) I thought of the Welsh town also, and for a moment also wondered it if might be the Supercalifrag....etc word Really fun acrostic.

Martin, glad I'm not the only one who thought it might be "bejeebers" lol

@gpome (5) goodness me, that sounds frustrating : ( I haven't come across THAT problem before, can't think how to be of help to you..... Have a wonderful time in Europe, a continent that I have come to love! cheers all...

For the second straight day I survived the puzzle intact, but, like yesterday, only with first aid from Nurse Check. I used to get through a fair number of Fridays and an occasional Saturday totally unassisted, but now I'm wondering if those days are behind me. Well, at least I haven't yet had to resort to that evil temptress, Madame Reveal. Am I going a bit overboard with all this anthropomorphizing? Well, yes. Sorry.

Never heard of PROXIMA CENTAURI, MARIN, or ENSOR, but I just don't get 48D. At best it seems very thin, almost off the wall. As anyone in the D.C. metro area would know, Joe GIBBS coached the Washington Redskins to three Super Bowl championships. By the way, let's go, Caps!

Clever theme, clever title, good theme answer symmetry.  Alternate title:  "Now you see it, now you don't"    Sphynx, it's SOAP, not SNAP.  Yes, Denise, I think you're right about "off" -- I had thought it should simply be "start a sentence".  Hardly ever see mistakes, though -- maybe there's a better explanation.

Sometimes it seems like half of solving the puzzle is removing my plausible but wrong entries: ionS before FEES, officeR before SCHOLAR, boar before REAP (sow like pig, not seed.) Nevertheless, a nice Sunday.

Only had to cheat for the Scottish possessive. Nice to see Ali McGraw in the grid; hadn't thought of her in years, so beautiful and confident.
joyM, SKA is a musical cousin of Reggae, in Jamaica, mon. :-)

sphynx - SOAP, not SNAP.

I think I will sleep on before commenting.

Regarding 83A, I think the makers and/or editors just neglected to delete "of" in their final version of the clue.

This was a wonderful puzzle, with one of the cleverest and funniest themes I can remember, including its perfect title. By the way, it may be just a coincidence but outside the theme answers I counted six other "it"s as well as six "ti"s.

I must say that I think 39A is kind of cavalier, as well as stretched so thin it would be see-through except that it's virtually opaque. Otherwise, congratulations to Mr. Madison and his collaborators on a puzzle that is marvelously rich in witty misdirection and slyness--including the "Sly" clue at 72A. It was an unalloyed pleasure to solve, and finally, one I was able to complete without help.

I put the equations from Gary 17 and Charles 29 into grapher and got four hyperbolas. As Gary said they don't all intersect at any one point. The point 2.66, 2.66, 5.30 is pretty close to hitting them all.
How to Write Like David Foster Wallace
"Life" by Keith Richards
Authenticity, by Milli Vanilli
Upper West Side Tea Party Mensa Chapters, Vol 6
Sex in the City: Vatican Edition

A Farewell to Armies: the Sad Demise of the Military-Industrial Complex

The Oral History of the World
The Complete Guide to the Universe
In Singapore prostitution is legal and regulated but pimping is illegal and fiercely prosecuted with fines, jail, and caning. Does that work better than prosecuting the Johns?

Last week I blogged about this problem as well. I've included a link to your article in an update to that post. Thanks for bringing attention to this issue. http://igneousquill.org/2011/04/17/child-sex-trafficking-in-the-united-s...

I firmly believe that as a nation, as a state, as a city, as a people, we have allowed ourselves to utterly abandon these children. We have for centuries winked at the men who go out to pay these little girls for sex, all the while knowing that they are abused, brutalized and imprisoned sex slaves beholden to inhumane barbaric pimps. That ordinary guy who heads out to a known street to hire a hooker is no better, perhaps even worse, than the pimp - he at least is supposed to know better, he is supposed to hold himself to a higher standard.

But we arrest the little girl, many of whom have no families who care enough to support them, we leave them no choice but to be bailed out by their pimp, beaten and put pack to work. Historically we know that when these pimps find these kids in bus, train stations or the streets they take them in and then rape them for days at a time till they are so brutalized and desensitized they do what they're told. Yet still, the 'john' gets off and the kid gets pushed out on to the street for the pimp for the next upstanding member of society to come along and pay for sex.

I say we start arresting, prosecuting and fining the 'johns' - with large fines and then use those fines to set up support systems for these kids. Let's stop winking at the 'johns' hiring 14 year old boys or girls for sex and let's prosecute them.

Thank you for recognizing one of the problems that we Americans like to sweep under
everyone else's rug.
Australia and Sweden certainly manage this better than we do.
I'm so glad this article was written. Let's get to work on helping these girls!

Nick Kristof, you suggest that we read Rachel Lloyd's memoir "Girls Like Us" - and you said Lloyd's book "is the best thing I know written on human trafficking of underage girls".. Powerful praise about the exposition of human trafficking of underage American girls, mostly runaways, who are turned into protitutes by pimps, johns and the whole sorry panoply of egregiously sick animals who prey on hapless and helpless girls and make their rich livings from the sex trade they have enslaved those victimized girls to ply.

What is so fascinating about your column is that it is a companion piece today to Maureen Dowd's column about the beatitude of Pope John Paul II
(Karol Wojtila) by Pope Benedict, his successor, the German Pope Ratzinger, and the need to "Hold the Halo" because John Paul was guilty of turning away from the crisis which was central in the Catholic Church during his entire ministry - the abuse by the priesthood of young boys all over the globe where Catholics worship in their parishes.

There is a wicked and fearful symbiosis in these two major abuses of our times - underage prostitution (not only in America but all over the world) - the vile and sickening sex trade in young women , and the worldwide, global, abuse of children by priests, which has gone on for years - last century, this century; it has not stopped and is an ongoing crime - paedophilia - as egregious as murder, for it kills the spirit of those boys and girls who are used by their priests because "there is nothing wrong, and this is what God wants and don't tell anyone". So many boys have lost their boyhood, their religion, their dignity and wholesomeness, their adult lives because of the predations of the priests their families admire , respect, adore and entertain in their homes. There is no answer to these dreadful problems of prostitution among underage girls in all the cities in America from coast to coast. No answer, either, to the issue of priestly abuse - beyond our comprehension. One can only hope that evil priests will be brought to justice somehow (what Abelard suffered is too good for them) and that pimps will be thrown into the slammer without their hats, sunglasses and fancy wheels. As for the johns, users and "clients" (too nice a word for them) who are buying these girls - may they suffer a debilitating and wasting disease and ASAP. Theirs' is not a "victimless" crime, and they are well aware that their lust for young prostitutes is as bad as the same wolfish lust the celibate, abstinent priest (sic) indulges himself in with the tenderest of lambs in his flock.. Major shames, Nick! And there is no answer, no solution to these tragic and traumatic ills of our society and culture. Alas.

First, thank you, Mr. Kristof, for drawing connections you do here—and for raising, once more, the question that never ceases to puzzle me: How can we be so compassionate, in certain circumstances, toward those from far, so callous toward our own?

I could say much about the complex nexus of sex, class, and, to a degree, race—about how teenage prostitution (or, to use your more accurate terms, the sexual trafficking of American girls)—touches upon all so many of our cultural pressure points... But even more, I suspect our failure of compassion, our quick turns to neglect or judgment, lie in the intimacy of domestic trafficking: not simply that these girls may be our daughters, but that their fates sharply illuminate our culture's failings in both the most public and private fora. It is domestic trafficking in every sense of the term, for all that parents do not actively sell their children.

And it is this domestic dimension, the very intimacy of this trafficking, that moves us to judge, condemn the victim—else we must needs judge, condemn, ourselves.

And two final points: How many of these girls are LGBT? And what about trafficked boys—boys who, if anything, are even more likely to be judged, condemned, abandoned than are girls?

The point is that there are far more men that are looking to buy sex than there are women that are willing (voluntarily) to be prostitutes. Therefore, the demand far exceeds the supply, and women are trafficked to create the additional supply.

TAKE ACTION! Backpage.com is a meeting place for traffickers, pimps, and their customers to sexually exploit women and children. Sign an online petition to shut down this marketing tool for sex traffickers: http://EndDemandNYC.org/
I would encourage anyone interested in this to google for Andrew Vachss, and read his web site. He also has a book series which touches on this topic.
